But He turns in His Mercy to all who call on Him. For those who arrogantly reject Him, the evil consequences of their rejection are inevitable, and must soon come to pass.

Name: The Poets
Verse: Ta. Sin. Mim.

Name: The Poets
Verse: These are verses of the Book that makes (things) clear.

Name: The Poets
Verse: It may be thou frettest thy soul with grief, that they do not become Believers.

Name: The Poets
Verse: If (such) were Our Will, We could send down to them from the sky a Sign, to which they would bend their necks in humility.

Name: The Poets
Verse: But there comes not to them a newly-revealed Message from (God) Most Gracious, but they turn away therefrom.

Name: The Poets
Verse: They have indeed rejected (the Message): so they will know soon (enough) the truth of what they mocked at!

Name: The Poets
Verse: Do they not look at the earth,- how many noble things of all kinds We have produced therein?

Name: The Poets
Verse: Verily, in this is a Sign: but most of them do not believe.

Name: The Poets
Verse: And verily, thy Lord is He, the Exalted in Might, Most Merciful.

Name: The Poets
Verse: Behold, thy Lord called Moses: "Go to the people of iniquity,-

Name: The Poets
Verse: "The people of the Pharaoh: will they not fear God?"

Name: The Poets
Verse: He said: "O my Lord! I do fear that they will charge me with falsehood:

Name: The Poets
Verse: "My breast will be straitened. And my speech may not go (smoothly): so send unto Aaron.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And (further), they have a charge of crime against me; and I fear they may slay me."

Name: The Poets
Verse: God said: "By no means! proceed then, both of you, with Our Signs; We are with you, and will listen (to your call).

Name: The Poets
Verse: "So go forth, both of you, to Pharaoh, and say: ’We have been sent by the Lord and Cherisher of the worlds;

Name: The Poets
Verse: "’Send thou with us the Children of Israel.’"

Name: The Poets
Verse: (Pharaoh) said: "Did we not cherish thee as a child among us, and didst thou not stay in our midst many years of thy life?

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And thou didst a deed of thine which (thou knowest) thou didst, and thou art an ungrateful (wretch)!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: Moses said: "I did it then, when I was in error.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "So I fled from you (all) when I feared you; but my Lord has (since) invested me with judgment (and wisdom) and appointed me as one of the apostles.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And this is the favour with which thou dost reproach me,- that thou hast enslaved the Children of Israel!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: Pharaoh said: "And what is the ’Lord and Cherisher of the worlds’?"

Name: The Poets
Verse: (Moses) said: "The Lord and Cherisher of the heavens and the earth, and all between,- if ye want to be quite sure."

Name: The Poets
Verse: (Pharaoh) said to those around: "Did ye not listen (to what he says)?"

Name: The Poets
Verse: (Moses) said: "Your Lord and the Lord of your fathers from the beginning!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: (Pharaoh) said: "Truly your apostle who has been sent to you is a veritable madman!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: (Moses) said: "Lord of the East and the West, and all between! if ye only had sense!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: (Pharaoh) said: "If thou dost put forward any god other than me, I will certainly put thee in prison!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: (Moses) said: "Even if I showed you something clear (and) convincing?"

Name: The Poets
Verse: (Pharaoh) said: "Show it then, if thou tellest the truth!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: So (Moses) threw his rod, and behold, it was a serpent, plain (for all to see)!

Name: The Poets
Verse: And he drew out his hand, and behold, it was white to all beholders!

Name: The Poets
Verse: (Pharaoh) said to the Chiefs around him: "This is indeed a sorcerer well- versed:

Name: The Poets
Verse: "His plan is to get you out of your land by his sorcery; then what is it ye counsel?"

Name: The Poets
Verse: They said: "Keep him and his brother in suspense (for a while), and dispatch to the Cities heralds to collect-

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And bring up to thee all (our) sorcerers well-versed."

Name: The Poets
Verse: So the sorcerers were got together for the appointment of a day well-known,

Name: The Poets
Verse: And the people were told: "Are ye (now) assembled?-

Name: The Poets
Verse: "That we may follow the sorcerers (in religion) if they win?"

Name: The Poets
Verse: So when the sorcerers arrived, they said to Pharaoh: "Of course - shall we have a (suitable) reward if we win?

Name: The Poets
Verse: He said: "Yea, (and more),- for ye shall in that case be (raised to posts) nearest (to my person)."

Name: The Poets
Verse: Moses said to them: "Throw ye - that which ye are about to throw!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: So they threw their ropes and their rods, and said: "By the might of Pharaoh, it is we who will certainly win!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: Then Moses threw his rod, when, behold, it straightway swallows up all the falsehoods which they fake!

Name: The Poets
Verse: Then did the sorcerers fall down, prostrate in adoration,

Name: The Poets
Verse: Saying: "We believe in the Lord of the Worlds,

Name: The Poets
Verse: "The Lord of Moses and Aaron."

Name: The Poets
Verse: Said (Pharaoh): "Believe ye in Him before I give you permission? surely he is your leader, who has taught you sorcery! but soon shall ye know!

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Be sure I will cut off your hands and your feet on opposite sides, and I will cause you all to die on the cross!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: They said: "No matter! for us, we shall but return to our Lord!

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Only, our desire is that our Lord will forgive us our faults, that we may become foremost among the believers!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: By inspiration we told Moses: "Travel by night with my servants; for surely ye shall be pursued."

Name: The Poets
Verse: Then Pharaoh sent heralds to (all) the Cities,

Name: The Poets
Verse: (Saying): "These (Israelites) are but a small band,

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And they are raging furiously against us;

Name: The Poets
Verse: "But we are a multitude amply fore-warned."

Name: The Poets
Verse: So We expelled them from gardens, springs,

Name: The Poets
Verse: Treasures, and every kind of honourable position;

Name: The Poets
Verse: Thus it was, but We made the Children of Israel inheritors of such things.

Name: The Poets
Verse: So they pursued them at sunrise.

Name: The Poets
Verse: And when the two bodies saw each other, the people of Moses said: "We are sure to be overtaken."

Name: The Poets
Verse: (Moses) said: "By no means! my Lord is with me! Soon will He guide me!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: Then We told Moses by inspiration: "Strike the sea with thy rod." So it divided, and each separate part became like the huge, firm mass of a mountain.

Name: The Poets
Verse: And We made the other party approach thither.

Name: The Poets
Verse: We delivered Moses and all who were with him;

Name: The Poets
Verse: But We drowned the others.

Name: The Poets
Verse: Verily in this is a Sign: but most of them do not believe.

Name: The Poets
Verse: And verily thy Lord is He, the Exalted in Might, Most Merciful.

Name: The Poets
Verse: And rehearse to them (something of) Abraham’s story.

Name: The Poets
Verse: Behold, he said to his father and his people: "What worship ye?"

Name: The Poets
Verse: They said: "We worship idols, and we remain constantly in attendance on them."

Name: The Poets
Verse: He said: "Do they listen to you when ye call (on them), or do you good or harm?"

Name: The Poets
Verse: They said: "Nay, but we found our fathers doing thus (what we do)."

Name: The Poets
Verse: He said: "Do ye then see whom ye have been worshipping,-

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Ye and your fathers before you?-

Name: The Poets
Verse: "For they are enemies to me; not so the Lord and Cherisher of the Worlds;

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Who created me, and it is He Who guides me;

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Who gives me food and drink,

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And when I am ill, it is He Who cures me;

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Who will cause me to die, and then to life (again);

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And who, I hope, will forgive me my faults on the day of Judgment.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "O my Lord! bestow wisdom on me, and join me with the righteous;

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Grant me honourable mention on the tongue of truth among the latest (generations);

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Make me one of the inheritors of the Garden of Bliss;

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Forgive my father, for that he is among those astray;

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And let me not be in disgrace on the Day when (men) will be raised up;-

Name: The Poets
Verse: "The Day whereon neither wealth nor sons will avail,

Name: The Poets
Verse: "But only he (will prosper) that brings to God a sound heart;

Name: The Poets
Verse: "To the righteous, the Garden will be brought near,

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And to those straying in Evil, the Fire will be placed in full view;

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And it shall be said to them: ’Where are the (gods) ye worshipped-

Name: The Poets
Verse: "’Besides God? Can they help you or help themselves?’

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Then they will be thrown headlong into the (Fire),- they and those straying in Evil,

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And the whole hosts of Iblis together.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "They will say there in their mutual bickerings:

Name: The Poets
Verse: "’By God, we were truly in an error manifest,

Name: The Poets
Verse: "’When we held you as equals with the Lord of the Worlds;

Name: The Poets
Verse: "’And our seducers were only those who were steeped in guilt.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "’Now, then, we have none to intercede (for us),

Name: The Poets
Verse: "’Nor a single friend to feel (for us).

Name: The Poets
Verse: "’Now if we only had a chance of return we shall truly be of those who believe!’"

Name: The Poets
Verse: Verily in this is a Sign but most of them do not believe.

Name: The Poets
Verse: And verily thy Lord is He, the Exalted in Might, Most Merciful.

Name: The Poets
Verse: The people of Noah rejected the apostles.

Name: The Poets
Verse: Behold, their brother Noah said to them: "Will ye not fear (God)?

Name: The Poets
Verse: "I am to you an apostle worthy of all trust:

Name: The Poets
Verse: "So fear God, and obey me.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "No reward do I ask of you for it: my reward is only from the Lord of the Worlds:

Name: The Poets
Verse: "So fear God, and obey me."

Name: The Poets
Verse: They said: "Shall we believe in thee when it is the meanest that follow thee?"

Name: The Poets
Verse: He said: "And what do I know as to what they do?

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Their account is only with my Lord, if ye could (but) understand.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "I am not one to drive away those who believe.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "I am sent only to warn plainly in public."

Name: The Poets
Verse: They said: "If thou desist not, O Noah! thou shalt be stoned (to death)."

Name: The Poets
Verse: He said: "O my Lord! truly my people have rejected me.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Judge Thou, then, between me and them openly, and deliver me and those of the Believers who are with me."

Name: The Poets
Verse: So We delivered him and those with him, in the Ark filled (with all creatures).

Name: The Poets
Verse: Thereafter We drowned those who remained behind.

Name: The Poets
Verse: Verily in this is a Sign: but most of them do not believe.

Name: The Poets
Verse: And verily thy Lord is He, the Exalted in Might, Most Merciful.

Name: The Poets
Verse: The ’Ad (people) rejected the apostles.

Name: The Poets
Verse: Behold, their brother Hud said to them: "Will ye not fear (God)?

Name: The Poets
Verse: "I am to you an apostle worthy of all trust:

Name: The Poets
Verse: "So fear God and obey me.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "No reward do I ask of you for it: my reward is only from the Lord of the Worlds.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Do ye build a landmark on every high place to amuse yourselves?

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And do ye get for yourselves fine buildings in the hope of living therein (for ever)?

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And when ye exert your strong hand, do ye do it like men of absolute power?

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Now fear God, and obey me.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Yea, fear Him Who has bestowed on you freely all that ye know.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Freely has He bestowed on you cattle and sons,-

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And Gardens and Springs.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Truly I fear for you the Penalty of a Great Day."

Name: The Poets
Verse: They said: "It is the same to us whether thou admonish us or be not among (our) admonishers!

Name: The Poets
Verse: "This is no other than a customary device of the ancients,

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And we are not the ones to receive Pains and Penalties!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: So they rejected him, and We destroyed them. Verily in this is a Sign: but most of them do not believe.

Name: The Poets
Verse: And verily thy Lord is He, the Exalted in Might, Most Merciful.

Name: The Poets
Verse: The Thamud (people) rejected the apostles.

Name: The Poets
Verse: Behold, their brother Salih said to them: "Will you not fear (God)?

Name: The Poets
Verse: "I am to you an apostle worthy of all trust.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "So fear God, and obey me.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "No reward do I ask of you for it: my reward is only from the Lord of the Worlds.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Will ye be left secure, in (the enjoyment of) all that ye have here?-

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Gardens and Springs,

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And corn-fields and date-palms with spathes near breaking (with the weight of fruit)?

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And ye carve houses out of (rocky) mountains with great skill.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "But fear God and obey me;

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And follow not the bidding of those who are extravagant,-

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Who make mischief in the land, and mend not (their ways)."

Name: The Poets
Verse: They said: "Thou art only one of those bewitched!

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Thou art no more than a mortal like us: then bring us a Sign, if thou tellest the truth!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: He said: "Here is a she-camel: she has a right of watering, and ye have a right of watering, (severally) on a day appointed.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Touch her not with harm, lest the Penalty of a Great Day seize you."

Name: The Poets
Verse: But they ham-strung her: then did they become full of regrets.

Name: The Poets
Verse: But the Penalty seized them. Verily in this is a Sign: but most of them do not believe.

Name: The Poets
Verse: And verily thy Lord is He, the Exalted in Might, Most Merciful.

Name: The Poets
Verse: The people of Lut rejected the apostles.

Name: The Poets
Verse: Behold, their brother Lut said to them: "Will ye not fear (God)?

Name: The Poets
Verse: "I am to you an apostle worthy of all trust.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "So fear God and obey me.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "No reward do I ask of you for it: my reward is only from the lord of the Worlds.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Of all the creatures in the world, will ye approach males,

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And leave those whom God has created for you to be your mates? Nay, ye are a people transgressing (all limits)!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: They said: "If thou desist not, O Lut! thou wilt assuredly be cast out

Name: The Poets
Verse: He said: "I do detest your doings."

Name: The Poets
Verse: "O my Lord! deliver me and my family from such things as they do!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: So We delivered him and his family,- all

Name: The Poets
Verse: Except an old woman who lingered behind.

Name: The Poets
Verse: But the rest We destroyed utterly.

Name: The Poets
Verse: We rained down on them a shower (of brimstone): and evil was the shower on those who were admonished (but heeded not)!

Name: The Poets
Verse: Verily in this is a Sign: but most of them do not believe.

Name: The Poets
Verse: And verily thy Lord is He, the Exalted in Might Most Merciful.

Name: The Poets
Verse: The Companions of the Wood rejected the apostles.

Name: The Poets
Verse: Behold, Shu’aib said to them: "Will ye not fear (God)?

Name: The Poets
Verse: "I am to you an apostle worthy of all trust.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "So fear God and obey me.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "No reward do I ask of you for it: my reward is only from the Lord of the Worlds.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Give just measure, and cause no loss (to others by fraud).

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And weigh with scales true and upright.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And withhold not things justly due to men, nor do evil in the land, working mischief.

Name: The Poets
Verse: "And fear Him Who created you and (who created) the generations before (you)"

Name: The Poets
Verse: They said: "Thou art only one of those bewitched!

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Thou art no more than a mortal like us, and indeed we think thou art a liar!

Name: The Poets
Verse: "Now cause a piece of the sky to fall on us, if thou art truthful!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: He said: "My Lord knows best what ye do."

Name: The Poets
Verse: But they rejected him. Then the punishment of a day of overshadowing gloom seized them, and that was the Penalty of a Great Day.

Name: The Poets
Verse: Verily in that is a Sign: but most of them do not believe.

Name: The Poets
Verse: And verily thy Lord is He, the Exalted in Might, Most Merciful.

Name: The Poets
Verse: Verily this is a Revelation from the Lord of the Worlds:

Name: The Poets
Verse: With it came down the spirit of Faith and Truth-

Name: The Poets
Verse: To thy heart and mind, that thou mayest admonish.

Name: The Poets
Verse: In the perspicuous Arabic tongue.

Name: The Poets
Verse: Without doubt it is (announced) in the mystic Books of former peoples.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.196: The word Zubur, used here, is plural of Zabar, which is mentioned in the Qur-in as the Book revealed to the prophet Da’ud. It has also been used in the Qur-in in generic sense of "Book" (LIV: 52). Here the word refers to the earlier Revelations.

Name: The Poets
Verse: Is it not a Sign to them that the Learned of the Children of Israel knew it (as true)?

Name: The Poets
Verse: Had We revealed it to any of the non-Arabs,

Name: The Poets
Verse: And had he recited it to them, they would not have believed in it.

Name: The Poets
Verse: Thus have We caused it to enter the hearts of the sinners.

Name: The Poets
Verse: They will not believe in it until they see the grievous Penalty;

Name: The Poets
Verse: But the (Penalty) will come to them of a sudden, while they perceive it not;

Name: The Poets
Verse: Then they will say: "Shall we be respited?"

Name: The Poets
Verse: Do they then ask for Our Penalty to be hastened on?

Name: The Poets
Verse: Seest thou? If We do let them enjoy (this life) for a few years,

Name: The Poets
Verse: Yet there comes to them at length the (Punishment) which they were promised!

Name: The Poets
Verse: It will profit them not that they enjoyed (this life)!

Name: The Poets
Verse: Never did We destroy a population, but had its warners -

Name: The Poets
Verse: By way of reminder; and We never are unjust.

Name: The Poets
Verse: No evil ones have brought down this (Revelation):

Name: The Poets
Verse: It would neither suit them nor would they be able (to produce it).

Name: The Poets
Verse: Indeed they have been removed far from even (a chance of) hearing it.

Name: The Poets
Verse: So call not on any other god with God, or thou wilt be among those under the Penalty.

Name: The Poets
Verse: And admonish thy nearest kinsmen,

Name: The Poets
Verse: And lower thy wing to the Believers who follow thee.

Name: The Poets
Verse: Then if they disobey thee, say: "I am free (of responsibility) for what ye do!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: And put thy trust on the Exalted in Might, the Merciful,-

Name: The Poets
Verse: Who seeth thee standing forth (in prayer),

Name: The Poets
Verse: And thy movements among those who prostrate themselves,

Name: The Poets
Verse: For it is He Who heareth and knoweth all things.

Name: The Poets
Verse: Shall I inform you, (O people!), on whom it is that the evil ones descend?

Name: The Poets
Verse: They descend on every lying, wicked person,

Name: The Poets
Verse: (Into whose ears) they pour hearsay vanities, and most of them are liars.

Name: The Poets
Verse: And the Poets,- It is those straying in Evil, who follow them:

Name: The Poets
Verse: Seest thou not that they wander distracted in every valley?-

Name: The Poets
Verse: And that they say what they practise not?-

Name: The Poets
Verse: Except those who believe, work righteousness, engage much in the remembrance of God, and defend themselves only after they are unjustly attacked. And soon will the unjust assailants know what vicissitudes their affairs will take!

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.1 : ’Ibis is a combination of three Abbreviated Letters, as to which, generally, see Appendix 1, printed at the end of S.ii.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.2 : Cf. v. 17, and n. 716. The comparison of Allah’s revelation with Light is continued.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.3 : "They" are the Pagans of Makkah. From a human point of view it was a great disappointment to Allah’s Messenger in the middle period of his Makkan ministry that the Makkan could not be brought to believe in the Truth.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.4 : If it had been Allah’s Will and Plan to force people’s will, He could quite easily have forced the Makkans. But His Will and Plan work differently. His revelation is meant to train man’s own will so that it conforms to Allah’s beneficent purpose.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.6 : They may laugh at Allah’s Message of righteousness, but they will soon see the power of Truth and realise the real significance of the movement which they opposed. Where were the Pagans of Makkah after Badr, and still more, after the bloodless surrender of Makkah? And the meaning may be applied universally in all history.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.7 : If evil has a little run in this life, let them not run away with the notion that the world is for evil. They have only to look round at the physical and moral world around them, and they would be undeceived. But they are blind and without the Faith (the Light) which would open their eyes.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.9 : One Who is able to carry out all His Will and Plans. See n. 2818 to xxii. 40.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.10 : The part of the story of Moses told here is how Moses felt diffident about undertaking his commission; how Allah reassured him; how he went to Pharaoh with "the Signs"; how Pharaoh and his people rejected him; how their blasphemy recoiled on themselves, but the cause of Allah triumphed; in other words the point here is the reaction of a wicked people to the light that was held up to them, considered in its relation to the mind of Allah’s Messenger.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.13 : As we should say in English, "My heart would fail me, and my tongue cleave to my mouth." Moses had an impediment in his speech, and his mission was risky: see next note. But Allah’s Plan works in wondrous ways. Aaron was given to assist him in his mission, and Moses’s shortcomings were transformed by Allah’s grace into power, so that he became the most powerful leader of Israel.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.14 : Moses was brought up in the palace of Pharaoh, as narrated in his personal story in xx. 3940 and n. 2563. When he was grown-up he saw an Egyptian smiling an Israelite, and as the Israelites were being generally oppressed by the Egyptians, Moses’s anger was roused, and he slew the Egyptian. He then fled to the Midianite country in the Sinai peninsula, where he received the divine commission. But the charge of slaying the Egyptian was hanging against him. He was also apparently quick-tempered. But Allah’s grace cured his temper and he became wise; his impediment in speech, for he stood up boldly to speak to Pharaoh; and his fear, for he dared the Egyptians with Allah’s Signs, and they were afraid of him.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.18 : There is here a little play of wit on the part of Pharaoh. When Moses speaks of the "Lord and Cherisher of the Worlds", Pharaoh says: "Who cherished you? Did we not bring you up as a child? Did you not grow up among us?" By implication Pharaoh suggest that he is the cherisher of Moses, and in any case Pharaoh laid claim to godhead himself.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.19 : Further, Pharaoh reminds Moses of his having slain the Egyptian, and taunts him: "You are not only a murderer: you are an ungrateful wretch" (using "fir again in a double sense) "to have killed one of the race that brought you up!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.20 : What is Moses’s reply? He is no longer afraid. He tells the whole truth, extenuating nothing in his own favour. "Yes I did it: but I did it under an error." There are three implications in this: "(1) I was wrong in doing it in a temper and in being hasty; (2) 1 was wrong in taking the law into my own hands, but I repented and asked for Allah’s pardon (xxviii. 15-16); (3) that was at a time when I was under your influence, but since then I am a changed man, as Allah has called me."

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.21 : He accounts for all his movements, much more than Pharaoh had asked for. He has nothing to hide. At that time he was under the influence of fear, and he had fled from him. Now he is serving Allah, the Lord of the Worlds. He has no fear: he is a messenger.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.22 : Pharaoh had called Moses ungrateful and reproached him with all the favours which Moses had received from the Egyptians. "What favours?" he says; "Do you count it also as a favour to me that you have enslaved my brethren the Children of Israel?" Moses was now speaking as a Prophet of Allah, not as an individual. Any individual favours he may have received were blotted out by the oppression of his people.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.23 : Moses having eliminated all personalities, the argument now comes up to the highest plane of all,-the attributes of Allah and Ms mercies. Moses had put forward this before, as implied in verse 16 above, but Pharaoh had twisted it into personalities. Now we come back to the real issue. It may have been in the same sitting, or it may have been in a later sitting.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.25 : Moses had stiffed up the wrath of Pharaoh both by putting forward the name of the One True God as against Pharaoh’s pretended godhead, and by suggesting that any man of judgment would understand Allah’s majesty. While Pharaoh turns to his people in indignation, Moses drives the nail in further: "He is the God of the heavens and the earth and all between: therefore He is also your God, and the God of your fathers from the beginning. Any other pretensions are false!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.27 : Pharaoh is further perturbed. In reply to Moses’s statement that Allah, the One True God is also the God of the Egyptians and Pharaoh also, Pharaoh says sarcastically to his Court: "Look at this ’Messenger’ of yours; he seems to be mad!" But Moses is not abashed. He boldly says what is the truth: "It is you who are mad! The God Whom I preach is the universal Lord,-of the East and of the West. He reigns wherever you go!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.29 : Now we come to the crisis. Pharaoh threatens Moses with prison for treason. Moses remains calm and stiff argues: "What if I show you a miracle? Will it convince you that I am not mad, and that I have behind me the Lord of all the Worlds?"

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.30 : The Egyptians were addicted to magic and sorcery. If a true miracle were shown to them, would they believe? Perhaps they would see the hollowness of their own magic. In fact this actually happened with the Egyptian sorcerers themselves and perhaps with the commonalty. But Pharaoh and his Court were too arrogant to accept Moses’s religion.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.33 : Cf. vii. 107-8. See the whole passage there, and the notes thereon.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.34 : In vii. 109 it is the Chiefs who say this. The fact is that it was a general consultation, and this was the general feeling, expressed in words by each to the others.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.38 : A day well-known: a solemn day of festival: see xx. 59. The object was to get together as large a concourse of people as possible. It was confidently expected that the Egyptian sorcerers with all their organisation would win with their tricks against these amateur Israelites, and so the State cult of the worship of Pharaoh would be fastened on the necks of the people more firmly than ever.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.40 : See the last note. The people are to come and witness the triumph of the State religion, so that they may become the more obedient to Pharaoh and more compliant with the demands of the priests. The State religion included magic and the worship of Pharaoh.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.41 : There was no such thing as pure loyalty to an exploiting ruler like this Pharaoh. The sorcerers, who were probably also priests, were venal, and they hoped to establish their own hold on both king and people by the further enrichment of themselves and their order.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.43 : The euphemism implies a taunt, as if Moses had said: "I know about your tricks! You pretend to throw ropes and rods, and make people believe they are snakes. But now come on!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.44 : Though Pharaoh claimed to be a god. And so they appeal to his "divine" power.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.45 : The sorcerers’ ropes and rods seemed to have become serpents, but the rod of Moses was mightier than all of them and quickly swallowed them up. So truth is more powerful than tricks and win expose and destroy them.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.49 : The soreerers knew that they had met something very different from their tricks. Allah’s power worked on them and they professed the True God. As they represented the intelligence of the community, it may be presumed that they carried the intelligence of Egypt with them and perhaps some of the commonalty, who were impressed by the dramatic scene! Hence Pharaoh’s anger, but it is the beginning of his decline!

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.51 : This is the core of the lesson enforced in this passage. What was the reaction of the environment to the Light or Message of Allah? (1) It transformed Moses so that he became a fearless leader, one of the foremost in faith. (2) From men like Pharaoh and his corrupt court, it called forth obstinacy, spite, and all the tricks and snares of evil, but Evil was defeated on its own ground. (3) The magicians were touched by the glorious Light of Allah, and they were ready to suffer tortures and death, their sole ambition (in their transformed state) being to be foremost in Faith!

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.52 : The rest of the story-of the plagues of Egypt-is passed over as not germane to the present argument. We come now to the story of Israel leaving Egypt, pursued by Pharaoh. Here again there are three contrasts: (1) the blind arrogance of the Egyptians, against the development of Allah’s Plan; (2) the Faith of Moses, against the fears of his people; and (3) the final deliverance of the Israelites against the destruction of the host of brute force.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.57 : In deference to almost unanimous authority I have translated this passage (verses 58-60) as if it were a parenthetical statement of Allah’s purpose.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.59 : The Children of Israel certainly inherited the gardens, springs, treasures, and honourable positions in Palestine after many years’ wanderings in the wilderness. But when they were false to Allah, they lost them again, and another people (the Muslims) inherited them when they were true in Faith. "Of such things": literally, "of them".

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.60 : The story is here resumed after the parenthesis of verses 58-60.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.62 : Guide me: i.e., show me some way of escape from danger. This actually happened for Pharaoh’s host was drowned. The faith of Moses stands in strong contrast to the fears of his people.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.64 : The miracle was twofold: (1) Moses with his people passed safely through the sea; and (2) Pharaoh and his great host were drowned in the sea.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.67 : As it was then, so it is now. In spite of the obvious Signs of Allah, people who are blind in their obstinate resistance to Truth accomplish their own destruction, while humble, persecuted men of Faith are transformed by the Light of Allah, and obtain salvation.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.68 : Nothing that the powers of evil can do, will ever defeat the merciful Purpose of Allah. Evil, in resisting good, will effect its own destruction.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.69 : For the argument of this Sura the incidents in Abraham’s life are not relevant and are not mentioned. What is mentioned is: (1) the steps by which he taught about the sin of false worship, in the form of a Dialogue; (2) the aims of a righteous man not only in his individual life, but for his ancestors and posterity, in the form of a Prayer; and (3) a picture of the Future Judgment, in the form of a vision. (1) is covered by verses 70-82; (2) by 83-87; and (3) by 88-102.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.71 : They want to show their true and assiduous devotion. But Abraham goes at once to the heart of the matter by asking: "To whom is your devotion paid? Is the object worthy of it?"

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.77 : The things that you worship are enemies to mankind: let me testify from my own personal experience: they are enemies to me: they can do me no good, but would lead me astray. Contrast with their impotence or their power of mischief the One True God Whom I worship: He created me and all the Worlds: He cherishes me and guides me; He takes care of me; and when I die, He will give me new life; He will forgive me and grant me final Salvation. Will you then come to this true worship? How can you doubt, after seeing the contrast of the one with the other? Is it not as the contrast between Light and Darkness?’

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.83 : Having shown clearly the distinction between the False and the True, Abraham now shows in the forin of a Prayer what his inmost wishes are. (1) He wants his own soul entightened with divine wisdom, and (2) his heart and life filled with righteousness; (3) he will not be content with working for himself or his own generation: his view extends to all future generations; (4) and of course he wishes to attain the goal of the righteous, the Garden of the Bliss of the Divine Countenance; but he is not content with this; for (5) he wants his father and relatives to share in his spiritual joy, so that he can proudly see all whom he can reach, in an honourable station (contrasted with disgrace) on the Day of Judgment.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.84 : Cf. xix. 50. The whole of the passage about Abraham there may be compared with this passage.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.88 : Now we have a vision of the Day of Judgment. Nothing will then avail except a pure heart; all sorts of the so-called "good deeds" of this world, without the motive of purity, will be useless. The contrast of the Garden of Bliss with the Fire of Misery will be plainly visible. Evil will be shown in its true colours,-isolated, helpless, cursing and despairing; and all chances will then have been lost.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.90 : The Good will only see good (the Garden of Bliss), and the Evil will only see evil (the Fire of Hell). The type of this contrast is shown to us in the world of our spiritual sense even in this life.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.94 : The false gods, being devils or personified false fancies, will be all involved in the punishment of Hell, together with their worshippers, and the ultimate sources of evil, the hosts of Iblis or Satan.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.97 : Error-manifest.- ’our error is now plainly manifest, but it should have been manifest to us before it was too late, because the Signs of Allah were always around us’. This will be said by the ungodly, whose eyes will then be fully opened.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.99 : They now see that the people who seduced them were themselves evil and subject to the penalities of evil, and their seductions were frauds. They feel that they ought to have seen it before. For who would deliberately follow the paths of those condemned to misery and punishment? How simple they were not to see the true character of their seducers, though they had been warned again and again against them! It was their own folly that made them accept such obviously false guidance!

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.102 : This apparent longing for a chance of retum is dishonest. If they were sent back, they would certainly retum to their evil ways: vi. 27-28. Besides, they have had numerous chances already in this life, and they have used them for mischief or evil.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.106 : Noah’s generation had lost all faith and abandoned themselves to evil. They had rejected the Message of messengers previously sent to the world. Noah was sent to them as one of themselves ("their brother"). His life was open before them: he had proved himself pure in heart and conduct (like the holy Prophet of Islam long after him), and worthy of every trust. Would they fear Allah and follow his advice? They could see that he had no ends of his own to serve. Would they not listen to him?

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.107 : Amin=one to whom a trust has been given, with several shades of meaning implied: e.g., (1) worthy of trust, (2) bound to deliver his trust, as a prophet is bound to deliver his Message, (3) bound to act entirely as directed by the trust, as a prophet is bound to give only the Message of Allah, and not add anything of his own, and (4) not seeking any interest of his own.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.110 : Note how the repetition rounds off the argument. See n. 3186 above.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.111 : The leaders of the people are speaking, as the Quraish leaders spoke in the time of the holy Prophet. "We know that thou hast been trustworthy in thy life. But look at the ’tag rag and bob tail’ that follow thee! Dost thou expect us to be Eke them or to be classed with them?" His answer was: "I know nothing against them; if they have done any wrong, or are only hypocrites, they are answerable to Allah; how can I drive them away from me, seeing that I am expressly sent to admonish all people?"

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.114 : Cf. xi. 29. All people who have faith have the right to come and listen to Allah’s Word and receive Allah’s Mercy, whether they are publicans and sinners, "Harijans" and low-caste men, men of "superior" or "inferior" races. The Prophet of Allah welcomes them all, as His Message has to shine before the whole world.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.116 : Two other cases occur to me where prophets of Allah were threatened with death by stoning: one was Abraham (xix. 46), and the other was Shu’aib (xi. 91). In neither case did the threats deter them from carrying out their mission. On the contrary the threats recoiled on those who threatened. So also did it happen in the case of Noah and the holy Prophet.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.119 : The story of Noah’s ]Flood is told in xi. 36-48. Here the point emphasised is Noah’s patience and constancy against threats, and the triumph and preservation of Allah’s Truth even though the world was ranged against it.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.121 : Ibis and the following verse run like a refrain throughout this Sura, and give the key-note to the subject-matter: how the Message of Allah is preached, how it is rejected in all ages, and how it triumphs at last, through the Mercy of Allah. See xxvi. 8-9, 68-69, 103-104, here (121-122), 139-140, 158-159, 174-175, and 190-191.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.123 : See n. 1040 to vii. 65 for the ’Ad people and their location. Here the emphasis is on the fact that they were materialists believing in brute force, and felt secure in their fortresses and resources, but were found quite helpless when Allah’s Message came and they rejected it.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.125 : See n. 3187 to xxvi. 107 above.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.128 : Any merely material civilisation prides itself on show and parade. Its votaries scatter monuments for all sorts of things in conspicuous places-monuments which commemorate deeds and events which are forgotten in a few generations! Cf. Shelley’s poem on Ozymandias: "I am Ozymandias, King of Kings! Look on my works, ye mighty, and despair! .... Boundless and bare the lonely and level sands stretch far away!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.130 : "Without any responsibility or consideration for those who come within your power?"

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.131 : See n. 3188 above.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.132 : The gifts are described generally, immaterial and material. "All that ye know" includes not only material things, but knowledge and the faculties by which knowledge may be used for human well-being, all that makes life beautiful and refined. "Cattle" means wealth generally, and "sons" means population and man-power. "Gardens and Springs" are things that contribute to the delight and pleasure of man.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.135 : "But you have misused all those gifts, and you will suffer the inevitable penalties for your misuse and or your ingratitude. "

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.136 : "We are not going to attend to you whether you preach to us or not." The construction of the second clause, "or be not among our admonishers" is a rapier cut at Hud, as if they had said: "Oh yes! we have heard plenty of admonishers like you!" See the next verse.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.137 : They said, as many of our modern enmies of religion say, "you are only reviving an ancient superstition, a dope of the crowd; there is no such thing as a Hereafter, or the sort of punishments you denounce!"

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.141 : For the Thamud people see n. 1043 to vii. 73. They were great builders in stone and a people with agricultural wealth, but they were an exclusive people and oppresed the poor. The point emphasised here is: "How long will your wealth last, especially if you depress your own people and dishonour Allah’s Signs by sacrilege?" The insciptions on the Thamud remains of rock-cut buildings in Al-Hijr are described in the Appendix at the end of this Sura.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.148 : The date palm flowers on a long spathe: when the Howers develop into fruit, the heavy ones hang with the load of fruit. The Thamud evidently were proud of their skill in producing corn and fruit and in hewing fine dwellings out of rocks, like the later dwellings of Roman times in the town of Petra.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.151 : They are told: "All your skill is very well; but cultivate virtue and do not follow the ways of those who put forward extravagant claims for men’s powers and material resources, or who lead lives of extravagance in luxury and self-indulgence; that makes mischief: but the door of repentance is open: win you repent?"

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.153 : They think he is talking like a madman, and they say so.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.155 : For this she-camel, see n. 1044 to vii. 73. Thee she-camel was to be a Sign and a test-case. Would they respect her rights of watering (and pasturage)?

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.157 : Their regrets were too late. They had themselves asked for a Sign. The Sign had been given to them in the she-camel, which their prophet Salih had put forward as a test-case. Would they, through that symbol, respect the law’ of equity by which all people had rights in water and in the gifts of nature? They refused to respect that law, and committed sacrilege by deliberately killing the she-camelel. They themselves came to an evil end.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.160 : The story of Lut (Lot) will be found in vii. 80-84: see n. 1049. Here the point is that the people of the Cities of the Plain were shamelessly addicted to vice against nature, and Lut’s warning only exasperated them, until they were destroyed by a shower of brimstone.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.167 : Their threat to cast him out has a grim significance in what actually happened. They were destroyed where they were, and he was glad to escape the dreadful Punishment according to the warning he had received.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.168 : He was only among them from a stem sense of duty. The whole atmosphere there was detestable to him, and he was glad to escape when duty no longer demanded his presence there. He prayed for deliverance from such surroundings.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.171 : This was Lut’s wife, who lingered behind and was among those who perished, See n. 1051 to vii. 83.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.173 : See n. 1052 to vii. 84.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.177 : For Shu’aib see n. 1054 to vii. 85.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.181 : They were a commercial people, but they were given to fraud, injustice, and wrongful mischief (by intermeddling with others). They are asked to fear Allah and follow His ways: it is He Who also created their predecessors among mankind, who never prospered by fraud and violent wrong-doing, but only justice and fair dealing.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.186 : They deny that he is a prophet or that they are doing wrong, or that any former generations behaved differently. They think they are the true exponents of human nature, and that such as he-idealists-are mere madmen.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.187 : ’If you really claim any real contact with Allah, let us see if you can bring down a piece of the sky to fall on us!’

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.188 : The challenge to bring down a piece of the sky was merely empty bravado, on the part of those who had called him a liar. But Shuaib does not insult them. He merely says: "Allah is the best judge of your conduct: what more can I say?" And Allah did punish them.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.189 : Perhaps a shower of ashes and cinders accompanying a volcanic eruption. If these people were the same as the Midianites, there was also an earthquake. See vii. 91 and n. 1063.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * It must have been a terrible day of wholesale destruction-earthquake, volcanic eruption, lava, cinders and ashes and rumbling noises to frighten those whose death was not instantaneous.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.191 : See above, n. 3193 to xxvi. 121.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.192 : The hostile reception of some of the previous Messengers having been mentioned, the special characteristics of the Qur-an are now referred to, to show (1) that it is true, and (2) that its rejection by the Makkan Pagans was of a piece with previous experience in the history of man: vested interests resist Truth, but it conquers.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.193 : Rah-ul-amin, the epithet of Gabriel, who came with the inspired Messages to the holy Prophet, is difficult to render in a single epithet in translation. In n. 3187 to xxvi. 107 I have described some of the various shades of meaning attached to the adjective Amin as applied to a Prophet. A further signification as attached to the Spirit of Inspiration is that it is the very quintessence of Faith and Truth, unlike the lying spirits which delude men with falsehood. On the whole, I think "the Spirit of Faith and Truth" will represent the original best here.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.194 : Qalb (Heart) signifies not only the seat of the affections, but also the seat of the memory and understanding. The process of inspiration is indicated by the impression of the divine Message on the inspired one’s heart, memory, and understanding, from which it was promulgated in human speech to the world. In this case the human speech was the perspicuous Arabic tongue, which would be plainly intelligible to the audience who would immediately hear it and be through them transmitted to all the world.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.197 : Many of the Jewish Doctors recognised the holy Prophet’s Message as a Message from Allah, e.g., ’Abdullah ibn Salam and Mukhairiq. The latter was a man of property, which he left for Islam. (There were also Christian monks and learned men who recognised the Prophet’s mission.)

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.199 : The turn of Arabia having come for receiving Allah’s Revelation, as was foretold in previous Revelations, it was inevitable that it should be in the Arab tongue through the mouth of an Arab. Otherwise it would have been unintelligible, and the Arabs could not have received the Faith and become the vehicles for its promulgation as actually happened in history.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.200 : "Thus" I think means through the medium of the Arabic language and the Arab people. The Qur-An penetrated through their language and their hearts. If the hard- hearted among them did not believe, they will see when the Penalty comes, how grievous a mistake they made. For the Penalty must come; even when they least expected it..They will be caught saying or thinking, "There is plenty of time; we can get another respite," when already it will have become too late for them to turn over a new leaf.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.204 : While some sinners out of negligence postpone the day of repentance till it is too late, others more bold actually ask out of bravado that Allah’s Punishment should be brought down on them at once, as they do not believe in Allah or His Punishment! The answer to them is: It will come soon enough-too soon, they will think, when it comes! Cf. xxii. 47 and notes.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.209 : Allah will grant much respite to sinners, for He is Most Gracious and Merciful. But all this respite will profit them nothing if they are merely immersed in the vanities of this world. Again and again, in spite of their rebellion and their rejection, does Allah send warnings and warners before the final Punishment of Justice. For Allah knows human weakness, and He win never be unjust in the least.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.210 : When anything extraordinary happens, there are always people desirous of putting the worst construction on it, and saying that it is the work of Satans. So when the Our-in came with its Message in wondrous Arabic, its enemies could only account for its power by attributing it to evil spirits! Such a beneficent message can never suit the purposes of Satans, nor would it be in their power to produce it. In fact Good and Evil are poles asunder, and Evil cannot even hear words of Good, of tender Pity for sinners and Forgiveness for the penitent!

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.215 : That is, be kind, gentle, and considerate with them, as a high flying bird is when she lowers her wing to her offspring. Cf. xvii. 24 and n. 2205, and xv. 88 and n. 201 1.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.216 : "Disobey thee" implied that they did something wrong, for the holy Prophet commanded what was right and forbade what was wrong. If, then, any of his flock did wrong the responsibility was not his, for he, like a good shepherd, tried to keep them right. What was he then to do? He would continue his teaching. But if any of them went so far wrong as to try to injure their own Teacher, Leader, and Guide, there was nothing for him to fear. His trust was only in Allah, and Allah sees and appraises all men’s actions at their true worth.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.219 : Literally, the standing and prostration are postures in Muslim prayer: the holy Prophet was equally earnest, sincere, and zealous in prayer for himself and for all his people. ’Me Prophet’s behaviour was exemplary in all the turns of fortune, and however foolish men may cavil, his purity and uprightness are fully known to Allah.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.221 : To people who maliciously suggested that the holy Prophet was possessed or inspired by evil spirits (xxvi. 210 above) the reply had already been made, but it is now declared that that suggestion is itself the work of Evil. Behind such suggestions are lying and wickedness, or at best some half-truths caught up in hearsay and twisted so as to show Allah in an evil light.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.224 : The Poets: to he read along with the exceptions mentioned in verse 227 below. Poetry and other arts are not in themselves evil, but may on the contrary be used in the service of religion and righteousness. But there is a danger that they may be prostituted for base purposes. If they are insincere ("they say what they do not") or are divorced from actual life or its goodness or its serious purpose, they may become instruments of evil or futility. They then wander about without any set purpose, and seek the depths (valleys) of human folly rather than the heights of divine light.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * v.227 : Poetry and the fine arts which are to be commended are those which emanate from minds steeped in Faith, which try to carry out in life the fine sentiments they express in their artistic work, aim at the glory of Allah rather than at self-glorification or the fulsome praise of men with feet of clay, and do not (as in Jihad) attack anything except aggressive evil. In this sense a perfect artist should be a perfect man. Perfection may not be attainable in this life, but it should be the aim of every man, and especially of one who wishes to become a supreme artist, not only in technique but in spirit and essentials. Among the commendable poets contemporary with the holy Prophet may be mentioned Hassan and Labid: the latter had the honour of being one of the seven whose poems were selected for "hanging" (the Mu’allaqat) in the Days of Ignorance.

Name: The Poets
Verse: * These were the scurrilous rhymesters, who were doomed to come to an evil end.

Name: The Ant
Verse: These are verses of the Qur’an,-a book that makes (things) clear;

Name: The Ant
Verse: A guide: and glad tidings for the believers,-

Name: The Ant
Verse: Those who establish regular prayers and give in regular charity, and also have (full) assurance of the hereafter.

Name: The Ant
Verse: As to those who believe not in the Hereafter, We have made their deeds pleasing in their eyes; and so they wander about in distraction.

Name: The Ant
Verse: Such are they for whom a grievous Penalty is (waiting); and in the Hereafter theirs will be the greatest loss.

Name: The Ant
Verse: As to thee, the Qur’an is bestowed upon thee from the presence of one who is wise and all-knowing.

Name: The Ant
Verse: Behold! Moses said to his family: "I perceive a fire; soon will I bring you from there some information, or I will bring you a burning brand to light our fuel, that ye may warn yourselves.

Name: The Ant
Verse: But when he came to the (fire), a voice was heard: "Blessed are those in the fire and those around: and glory to God, the Lord of the worlds.

Name: The Ant
Verse: "O Moses! verily, I am God, the exalted in might, the wise!....

Name: The Ant
Verse: "Now do thou throw thy rod!" But when he saw it moving (of its own accord)as if it had been a snake, he turned back in retreat, and retraced not his steps: "O Moses!" (it was said), "Fear not: truly, in My presence, those called as apostles have no fear,-

Name: The Ant
Verse: "But if any have done wrong and have thereafter substituted good to take the place of evil, truly, I am Oft-Forgiving, Most Merciful.

Name: The Ant
Verse: "Now put thy hand into thy bosom, and it will come forth white without stain (or harm): (these are) among the nine Signs (thou wilt take) to Pharaoh and his people: for they are a people rebellious in transgression."

Name: The Ant
Verse: But when Our Signs came to them, that should have opened their eyes, they said: "This is sorcery manifest!"

Name: The Ant
Verse: And they rejected those Signs in iniquity and arrogance, though their souls were convinced thereof: so see what was the end of those who acted corruptly!

Name: The Ant
Verse: We gave (in the past) knowledge to David and Solomon: And they both said: "Praise be to God, Who has favoured us above many of his servants who believe!"

Name: The Ant
Verse: And Solomon was David’s heir. He said: "O ye people! We have been taught the speech of birds, and on us has been bestowed (a little) of all things: this is indeed Grace manifest (from God.)"

Name: The Ant
Verse: And before Solomon were marshalled his hosts,- of Jinns and men and birds, and they were all kept in order and ranks.

Name: The Ant
Verse: At length, when they came to a (lowly) valley of ants, one of the ants said: "O ye ants, get into your habitations, lest Solomon and his hosts crush you (under foot) without knowing it."

Name: The Ant
Verse: So he smiled, amused at her speech; and he said: "O my Lord! so order me that I may be grateful for Thy favours, which thou hast bestowed on me and on my parents, and that I may work the righteousness that will please Thee: And admit me, by Thy Grace, to the ranks of Thy righteous Servants."

Name: The Ant
Verse: And he took a muster of the Birds; and he said: "Why is it I see not the Hoopoe? Or is he among the absentees?

Name: The Ant
Verse: "I will certainly punish him with a severe penalty, or execute him, unless he bring me a clear reason (for absence)."

Name: The Ant

Name: The Ant

Name: The Ant

Name: The Ant

Name: The Ant

Name: The Ant

Name: The Ant

Name: The Ant

Name: The Ant

Name: The Ant

Name: The Ant

Name: The Ant

Name: The Ant

Name: The Ant

Name: The Ant

Name: The Ant
Verse: But We saved him and his family, except his wife; her We destined to be of those who lagged behind.

Name: The Ant
Verse: And We rained down on them a shower (of brimstone): and evil was the shower on those who were admonished (but heeded not)!

Name: The Ant
Verse: Say: Praise be to God, and Peace on his servants whom He has chosen (for his Message). (Who) is better?- God or the false gods they associate (with Him)?

Name: The Ant
Verse: Or, Who has created the heavens and the earth, and Who sends you down rain from the sky? Name: The Ant
Verse: Or, Who has made the earth firm to live in; made rivers in its midst; set thereon mountains immovable; and made a separating bar between the two bodies of flowing water? (can there be another) god besides God? Nay, most of them know not.

Verse: Or, Who listens to the (soul) distressed when it calls on Him, and Who relieves its suffering, and makes you (mankind) inheritors of the earth? (Can there be another) god besides God? Little it is that ye heed!

Name: The Ant
Verse: Or, Who guides you through the depths of darkness on land and sea, and Who sends the winds as heralds of glad tidings, going before His Mercy? (Can there be another) god besides God?- High is God above what they associate with Him!

Name: The Ant
Verse: Or, Who originates creation, then repeats it, and who gives you sustenance from heaven and earth? (Can there be another) god besides God? Say, "Bring forth your argument, if ye are telling the truth!"

Name: The Ant
Verse: Say: None in the heavens or on earth, except God, knows what is hidden: nor can they perceive when they shall be raised up (for Judgment).

Name: The Ant
Verse: Still less can their knowledge comprehend the Hereafter: Nay, they are in doubt and uncertainty thereanent; nay, they are blind thereunto!

Name: The Ant
Verse: The Unbelievers say: "What! when we become dust,- we and our fathers,- shall we really be raised (from the dead)?

Name: The Ant
Verse: "It is true we were promised this,- we and our fathers before (us): these are nothing but tales of the ancients."

Name: The Ant
Verse: Say: "Go ye through the earth and see what has been the end of those guilty (of sin)."

Name: The Ant
Verse: But grieve not over them, nor distress thyself because of their plots.

Name: The Ant
Verse: They also say: "When will this promise (come to pass)? (Say) if ye are truthful."

Name: The Ant
Verse: Say: "It may be that some of the events which ye wish to hasten on may be (close) in your pursuit!"

Name: The Ant
Verse: But verily thy Lord is full of grace to mankind: Yet most of them are ungrateful.

Name: The Ant
Verse: And verily thy Lord knoweth all that their hearts do hide. As well as all that they reveal.

Name: The Ant
Verse: Nor is there aught of the unseen, in heaven or earth, but is (recorded) in a clear record.

Name: The Ant

Name: The Ant
Verse: And it certainly is a Guide and a Mercy to those who believe.

Name: The Ant
Verse: Verily thy Lord will decide between them by His Decree: and He is Exalted in Might, All-Knowing.

Name: The Ant
Verse: So put thy trust in God: for thou art on (the path of) manifest Truth.

Name: The Ant
Verse: Truly thou canst not cause the dead to listen, nor canst thou cause the deaf to hear the call, (especially) when they turn back in retreat.

Name: The Ant

Name: The Ant

Name: The Ant
Verse: See they not that We have made the Night for them to rest in and the Day to give them light? Verily in this are Signs for any people that believe!

Name: The Ant
Verse: And the Day that the Trumpet will be sounded - then will be smitten with terror those who are in the heavens, and those who are on earth, except such as God will please (to exempt): and all shall come to His (Presence) as beings conscious of their lowliness.

Name: The Ant
Verse: Thou seest the mountains and thinkest them firmly fixed: but they shall pass away as the clouds pass away: (such is) the artistry of God, who disposes of all things in perfect order: for he is well acquainted with all that ye do.

Name: The Ant
Verse: If any do good, good will (accrue) to them therefrom; and they will be secure from terror that Day.

Name: The Ant
Verse: And if any do evil, their faces will be thrown headlong into the Fire: "Do ye receive a reward other than that which ye have earned by your deeds?"

Name: The Ant
Verse: For me, I have been commanded to serve the Lord of this city, Him Who has sanctified it and to Whom (belong) all things: and I am commanded to be of those who bow in Islam to God’s Will,-

Name: The Ant
Verse: And to rehearse the Qur’an: and if any accept guidance, they do it for the good of their own souls, and if any stray, say: "I am only a Warner".

Name: The Ant
Verse: And say: "Praise be to God, Who will soon show you His Signs, so that ye shall know them"; and thy Lord is not unmindful of all that ye do.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.1 : See n. 3137 to xxvi. 1.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.2 : Revelation is here presented in three aspects: (1) it explains things, the attributes of Allah, our own position, and the world around; (2) it directs us to right conduct and keeps us from evil; and (3) to those who have Faith and accept its guidance, it gives the good news of forgiveness, purification, and the achievement of salvation.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.4 : Those who reject Allah and follow Evil have a good conceit of themselves. Their deeds are pleasing to no one else. As they have rejected Allah’s guidance, they are allowed to hug their own self-conceit, and given further respite for repentance. But they follow their own whims and wander about in distraction, as they have no standards such as guide the godly.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.5 : The account will then be made up, and they will be found to be terribly in loss. They will be the worst in loss, for all their self-complacency.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.7 : Cf. xx. 9-24. Both there and here there is a reference to the dawn of Revelation in the heart of Moses. The points there emphasised will be found in the notes to that passage. Here the emphasis is on the wonderful nature of the Fire and the wonderful way in which Moses was transformed at the touch of the Light. He was travelling in the Sinai desert with his family. Seeking ordinary light, he came upon a Light which took him to the highest signs of Allah. No doubt all his inner history had prepared him for his great destiny. It is the inner history that matters, and not the place or position of a man in the eyes of his ordinary fellows.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.8 : Those: in the original the pronoun is in the singular, "man", which is often used with a plural meaning.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.10 : Moses was now transported into an entirely new world. What he had taken to be an ordinary fire was a gleam of the heavenly light. His own rod or staff was no longer the dead piece of wood that had hitherto supported him. It became instinct with life, a life that moved, and had the power of offence and defence in it, as all living Good must have in its fight with Evil. His own transformation is described in the next note.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * In this great, new, wonderful world, that was opening out to Moses, he had to get his vision adjusted to his new surroundings, as an ordinary man has to adjust his sight before he can see in any very strong light that is new to him. The staff which had become alive as a snake frightened him: yet it was to be his own instrument of work in his new mission. All fear was to be cast out of his mind, as befitted a man chosen by Allah.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.11 : His slaying the Egyptian (n. 3146 to xxvi. 14), however defensible from certain aspects, was yet something from his past that had to be washed off, and Allah, Oft- Forgiving, Most Merciful, did it out of His abounding Grace. Nay, more; he was given a pure, Radiant Hand, as a Sign from Allah, as stated in the next verse.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.12 : Cf. xx. 22. There the expression is: "Draw thy hand close to thy side." As far as the physical act is concerned, the expressions there and here mean the same thing. Moses had a loose-fitting robe. If he put his hand within the folds of the robe, it would go to his bosom on the side of his body opposite to that from which his hand came; i.e., if it was his right hand it would go to the left side of his bosom. The hand comes out white and radiant, without a stain. Ordinarily if the skin becomes white it is a sign of disease or leprosy. Here it was the opposite. It was a sign of radiance and glory from the higher Light.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * The nine Signs: see n. 1091 to vii. 133.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.13 : The Signs should have clearly opened the eyes of any persons who honestly examined them and thought about them. Those who rejected them were perverse and were going against their own light and inner conviction. That was the aggravating feature of their sin.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.15 : Cf. xxi. 78-82. "Knowledge" means such knowledge as leads up to the higher things in life, the Wisdom that was shown in their decisions and judgments, and the understanding that enabled them to fulfil their mission in life. They were both just men and prophets of Allah. The Bible, as we have it, is inconsistent: on the one hand it calls David "a man after God’s own heart" (I Samuel, xiii. 14, and Acts xiii. 22); and the Christians acclaim Christ as a son of David; but on the other hand, horrible crimes are ascribed to him, which, if he had committed them, would make him a monster of cruelty and injustice. About Solomon, too, while he is described as a glorious king, there are stories of his lapses into sin and idolatry. The Muslim teaching considers them both to be men of piety and wisdom, and high in spiritual knowledge.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * They ascribed, as was proper, their knowledge, wisdom, and power to the only true Source of all good, Allah.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.16 : The point is that Solomon not only inherited his father’s kingdom but his spiritual insight and the prophetic office, which do not necessarily go from father to son-

Name: The Ant
Verse: * Speech of Birds. The spoken word in human speech is different from the means of communication which birds and animals have between each other. But no man can doubt that they have means of communication with each other, if he only observes the orderly flight of migratory birds or the regulated behaviour of ants, bees, and other creatures who live in communities. The wisdom of Solomon consisted in understanding these things-in the animal world and in the lower fringes of human intelligence.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * "Everything": Solomon was a king of power and authority; outside his kingdom he had influence among many neighbouring peoples; he had knowledge of birds, and beasts and plants; he was just and wise, and understood men; and above all, he had spiritual insight, which brought him near to Allah. Thus he had something of all kinds of desirable gifts. And with true gratitude he referred them to Allah, the Giver of all gifts.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.17 : Besides the literal meaning, there are two symbolical meanings. (1) All his subjects of varying grades of intelligence, taste, and civilization, were kept in due order and cooperation, by his discipline, justice, and good government. (2) The gifts of various kinds, which he possessed (see last note), he used in proper order and coordination, as if they were a well disciplined army, thus getting the best possible results from them.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.18 : This verse and the next, read together, suggest the symbolical meaning as predominant. The ant, to outward appearance, is a very small and humble creature. In the great pomp and circumstances of the world, she (generic feminine in Arabic) may be neglected or even trampled on by a people who mean her no harm. Yet, by her wisdom, she carries on her own life within her own sphere ("habitations") unmolested, and makes a useful contribution to the economy of the world. So there is room for the humblest people in the spiritual world.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.19 : The counterpart to the position of the humble ant is the position of a great king like Solomon. He prays that his power and wisdom and all other gifts may be used for righteousness and for the benefit of all around him. The ant being in his thoughts, we may suppose that he means particularly in his prayer that he may not even unwittingly tread on humble beings in his preoccupations with the great things of the world.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * "Me righteousness which pleases the world is often very different from the righteousness which pleases Allah. Solomon prays that he may always take Allah’s Will as his standard, rather than the standards of men.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * In the Kingdom of Allah, righteousness is the badge of citizenship. And although there are great and noble grades (see n. 586 to iv. 69), the base of that citizenship is the universal brotherhood of righteousness. The greatest in that Kingdom are glad and proud to pray for that essential badge.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.20 : Solomon was no idle or easy-going king. He kept all his organisation strictly up to the mark, both his armies literally and his forces (metaphorically). His most mobile arm was the Birds, who were light on the wing and flew and saw everything like efficient scouts. One day he missed the Hoopoe in his muster. The Hoopoe is a light, graceful creature, with elegant plumage of many colours, and a beautiful yellow crest on his head, which entities him to be called a royal bird.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.22 : Saba may reasonably be identified with the Biblical Sheba (I Kings x. 1-10). It is further referred to in the Sura called after its name: xxxiv. 15-20. It was a city in Yemen, said to have been three days’ journey (say 50 miles) from the city of San’a. A recent German explorer, Dr. Hans Helfritz, claims to have located it in what is now Hadhramaut territory. The famous dam of Maarib made the country very prosperous, and enabled it to attain a high degree of civilization ("provided with every requisite" in the next verse). The Queen of Sheba therefore rightly held up her head high until she beheld the glories of Solomon.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.23 : The Queen of Sheba (by name Bilqis in Arabian tradition) came apparently from Yemen, but she had affinities with Abyssinia and possibly ruled over Abyssinia also. The Habasha tribe (after whom Abyssinia was named) came from Yemen. Between the southern coast of Yemen and the north-eastern coast of Abyssinia there are only the Straits of Bab-al-Mandab, barely twenty miles across. In the 10th or llth century B.C. there were frequent invasions of Abyssinia from Arabia, and Solomon’s reign of 40 years is usually synchronised with B.C. 992 to 952. The Sabaean and Himyarite alphabets in which we find the south Arabian pre-Islamic inscriptions, passed into Ethiopic, the language of Abyssinia. The Abyssinians possess a traditional history called "The Book of the Glory of Kings" (Kebra Nagast), which has been translated from Ethiopic into English by Sir E.A. Wallis Budge (Oxford, 1932). It gives an account of the Queen of Sheba and her only son Menyelek 1, as founders of the Abyssinian dynasty.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * Provided with every requisite: I take this to refer not only to the abundance of spices and gems and gold in her country, but to sciences and arts, as well.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.24 : The ancient religion of the people of Saba (the Himyar or Sabaeans) consisted in the worship of the heavenly bodies, the sun, the planets, and the stars. Possibly the cult was connected with that of Chaldaea, the home-land of Abraham: see vi. 75-79 and notes thereon. Yemen had easy access to Mesopotamia and the Persian Gulf by way of the sea, as well as with Abyssinia. That accounts for the Christians of Najran and the Jewish dynasty of kings (e.g. Zu-Nuwas, d. 525 A.D.) who persecuted them in the century before Islam,-also for the Christian Abyssinian Governor Abraha and his discomfiture in the year of the Prophet’s birth (S.cv.), say 570 A.D. Jewish-Christian influences were powerful in Arabia in the sixth century of the Christian era. The religion of these Sabaeans (written in Arabic with a Sin) should not be confounded with that of the Sabians (with a Sad), as to whom see n. 76 to ii. 62.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.25 : The false worship of the Sabaeans is here exposed in three ways: (1) that they were self-satisfied with their own human achievements, instead of looking up to Allah; and (2) that the light of the heavenly bodies which they worshipped was only dependent on the true Light of Allah, which extends over heaven and earth; the Creator should be worshipped rather than His Creation; and (3) Allah knows the hidden secrets of men’s minds as well as the objects which they openly profess: are false worshippers really only worshipping their own selves, or the "sins they have a mind to" and are therefore afraid to go to Allah, Who knows all?

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.26 : The messenger (Hoopoe) is a pious bird, as befits a messenger of Solomon. After mentioning the false worship of the Sabaeans, he pronounces the Creed of Unity, and emphasises Allah’s attribute as Lord of the Great Throne, in order to make it clear that whatever may be the magnificence of a human throne such as he has described (in verse 23), he is not in any way misled from his loyalty to Solomon, the exponent of the true Religion of Unity.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.27 : Solomon does not doubt his messenger’s plea that he has scouted a new country, but wants to test whether he has loosened the rein of his imagination in describing its splendours or its worship.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.30 : Solomon expressly begins his letter with the formula of the true and universal Religion of Unity, and he invites to the true Faith the new people with whom he establishes honourable relations, not for worldly conquest but for the spreading of the Light of Allah.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.34 : The character of Queen Bilqis, as disclosed here, is that of a ruler enjoying great wealth and dignity, and the full confidence of her subjects. She does nothing without consulting her Council, and her Council are ready to carry out her commands in all things. Her people are manly, loyal, and contented, and ready to take the field against any enemy of their country. But their queen is predent in policy, and is not willing to embroil her country in war. She has the discrimination to see that Solomon is not like ordinary kings who conquer by violence. Perhaps in her heart she has a ray of the divine light already, though her people are yet Pagans. She wishes to carry her people with her in whatever she does, because she is as loyal to them as they are to her. An exchange of presents would probably establish better relations between the two kingdoms. And perhaps she anticipates some spiritual understanding also, a hope which was afterwards realised. In Bilqis we have a picture of womanhood, gentle, prudent, and able to tame the wider passions of her subjects.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.36 : Poor Bilqis! she thought she had arranged with womanly tact to conciliate Solomon, and at the same time pacify her warlike subjects! But the effect of the embassy with presents was the very opposite. Solomon took it as an insult that she should send her presents instead of her submission to the true Religion! He flung back the presents at her, as much as to say, "Let these baubles delight your own hearts! Allah has blessed me with plenty of worldly goods, and something infinitely better, viz.; His Light and Guidance! Why do you say nothing about that?"

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.38 : The throne is symbolical of power and dignity. So far her throne was based on material wealth: Solomon is going to alter it to a basis of Faith and the Religion of Unity.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.39 : Ifrit: a large, powerful jinn.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.40 : Solomon was thankful to Allah that he had men endowed with such power, and he had the throne of Bilqis transported to his Court and transformed as he desired, without Bilqis even knowing it.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * If Solomon had been ungrateful to Allah, i.e., if he had worked for his own selfish or worldly ends, he could have used the brute strength of ’Ifrit to add to his worldly strength and glory. Instead of it he uses the higher magic of the Book,-Of the Spirit-to transform the throne of Bilqis for her highest good, which means also the highest good of her subjects, by the divine Light. He had the two alternatives, and he chooses the better, and he thus shows his gratitude to Allah for the Grace He had given him.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * Man’s gratitude to Allah is not a thing that benefits Allah, for Allah is high above all needs: it benefits a man’s own soul and gives him higher rank in the life to come. Per contra, man’s ingratitude will not detract from Allah’s Glory and Honour or the value of Allah’s generous gifts to man: for Allah is supreme in honour, glory, and generosity. Karim in Arabic involves all three significations.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.41 : The throne having been disguised, it will be a test to see whether Bilqis recognises it as her own or not.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.42 : Bilqis stands the test. She knows it was her throne, yet not exactly the same, for it was now much better. And she is proud of her good fortune, and acknowledges, for herself and her people, with gratitude, the light which was given to them by Allah, by which they recognised Allah’s prophet in Solomon, and received the true Religion with all their will and heart and soul.

Name: The Ant
Verse: * v.43 : Some Commentators and Translators adopt an alternative construction for the last clause of the last verse and the first clause of this verse.
